document.text: SUMMARY. 1. Mr. Swanson is the only con gressman from Virginia whose name was mentioned in the report of Postmaster General Bristow in con nection with the frauds of Beavers. 2. With two exceptions, Mr. Swansons name is connected with that of Beavers in the report of Gen eral Bristow oftener than the name of any other congressman. 3. Special reference is made by Holmes Conrad and Charles Bona parte, now secretary of the navy, to .the failure of Mr. Swanson and other congressmen involved to report the fraudulent acts of Beayers to the postmaster general and to cougress. 4. Beavers notified Mr. Swanson hat improper allowance would be continued as a favor to him because of his interest in the mutter. 5. Mr. Swanson shoitly after ceased to- I e a member of the com mittee on Postoffices and Post Roads. C r a n d a l M a c k ey , Commonwealths Attorney of Alex andria County, Va.

document.text: Unusually Large A ttendanceInter esting M urder Trial. There was au unusually large at tendance of the sovereigns from every part of the county on last Thursday, the regular term of the County Court. Mauy of them were doubtless attracted by the wide spread interest in the trial of the negroes George Flowers aud Charles Robertson who had been indicted aud imprisoned for the murder of Bob Boler near Spout Spring, on the uight of the 4th of January last. The parties indicted and the import ant witnesses had all made fiatly contradictory statements and an im penetrable mystery seemed to overhang the tragedy. There bad been a negro frolic and dance, the parliciputs, male and female,- be coming uproarious from whiskey. On the way home Bob Boler, Letitia Carson, George Flowers aud Charles Robertson were walking together apart from the othei s. A scuffle en sued between George Flowers and Bob Boler they were separated aud the puny walked on a few paces when pistol shots were heard and Bob Boler fell to the ground mort ally wounded, ana his dead body was left in the middle of the road. These were all of the facts about which there was direct, uncontra- dicted testimony. A jury was empannelled in the case of George Flowers, without de lay or difficulty,consisting of the fol io wiug persons F. G. Thorpe, C. M. Diiukard, Seaborn Gilbert, Fielding Rogers, Ro. W. Morris, Jas. W. Paris, Samuel J. Lee, Samuel Rauson, P. H. Wooldridge, T. L. Cralie, W. T. Marshall, and Alouzu Hamilton. Mr. S. L. Ferguson, the uewly appointed Commonwealths Attorney, assisted by Hon. H. D. Flood, prosecuted the case and Col. R. B. Poore defended the accused. Mr. Fergusou managed the case with ability and gave abundant evi dence that he will make an efficient States Attorney. Col. Poore and Mr. Flood threw their utmost ener gies iuto the case, aud it is unneces sary to add that their efforts were vigorous and brilliant. The case occupied two days, and on Friday alternoou the jury brought in a ver dict of guilty and awarded the ac cused tea years in the peuitentiary. The counsel for the Commonwealth demanded only a verdict for murder iu the second decree, for which the punishment is confinement in the penitentiary admitting to the jury that they were unable to establish the ingredient of premeditation necessary - to elevate the homicide to murder iu the first degree. Col. Poore moved the Court to set aside the verdict and award the prisoner a new trial, upon the following grounds First That the verdict was con trary to the law and the evidence. Second That .he Attorney for tbe Commonwealth commented on the fact that the prisoner was not

document.text: Trial of the Flood-Flanagan Case Set for nay 6th. It was a case of rain outside and Flood inside yesterday, and a gen eral all-round April-fool for those who attended the Police Court in expectation that a result would be reached in the cause of Senator H. D. Flood, who is charged with an assault upon Senator W. M. Flana gan, of Powhatan. The difficulty between the sena tors occurred during the closing days of the legislative session, and the trial was set for to-day from an examination held early m the past month. At an early hour yesterday morn ing, men began to arrive, and at 10 oclock the court-room was crowded to its utmost capacity, for all thought that the much-discussed case would be finally determined. It was a little after 10 oclock when Justice Crutchfield called the case of H. D. Flood,and immediately the hum and buzz of the expectant throng caused Sergeant Thomas to rap vigorously for order. In the row of seats reserved for the attorneys sat Commonwealths- Attorney Harry Smith, and neur him sat Senator Flanagan, who was not represented by any assistant in the prosecution. General Edgar Allan, who was in the court in the former hearing was not present, and Judge Waddill, another friend of Mr. Flanagan was also absent. Senator Flood occupied a chair between Senator Conway R. Sands and Mr. Charles V. Meredith his counsel. Justice Crutchfield called the following witnesses Malcolm A. Coles, H. L. Maynard, 6. T. Snead, F. B. Watkins, Dr. Pierce, Dr. Jeffries, Dr. Michaux, O. T. Crump, James R. Werth, Morris Parr, Mor ris Evws, Major Robert Stiles, Frank Perkins, and Norman Ran dolph. He then announced that a number of the witnesses had not responded to their names, and the list was recalled. MR. EVANS ABSENT. Mr. Flanagan had then come in side the rail just before the Justice. He stated that Mr. Morris Evans, was not present. Mr. Smith asked Mr. Flanagan if he thought they could get along without Mr. Evans, and Mr. Flana gan replied that he considered Mr. Evans one of the most important of all the witnesses. It then became apparent that the case would have again to be post poned. Mr. Evans lives in Powha tan and was expected on the Alle ghany road from Columbia this morning. Justice Crutchfield had the railroad office telephoned to and found that the train had ar rive on time. It was then suggested that possibly Mr. Evans had been unable to reach the railroad on ac count of the high water in the river near Columbia. Justice Crutchfield announced that he was very sorry to be com pelled to again continue the case, as the witnesses were many of them, brought from some distance, and that the expense to the state was large. Mr. Smith here jocularly remarked that as many of the witnesses were members of the Legislature, they were also of course opposed to in creasing the criminal expenses of the State.

document.text: No Democratic primary elec tion will be held in Appomattox county this year, according to Fourth District Representative Watkins M. Abbitt, who is also chairman of the Appomattox County Democratic Committee. There will be no primary be cause no candidates other than incumbents in various county offices filed to run in a Demo cratic primary. Deadline for filing was Wed., July 14. Incumbent county o f f i c e r s who filed before the deadline with the Democratic Committee chairman will, of course, be running as Democratic candid ates in the general election of Tuesday, Nov. 9. Other candidates for county offices have indicated their in tentions to run as Independent candidates in the November election, and a contest has de veloped for the office of county treasurer. Incumbent county treasurer is John Garland Plunkett. Announced Independent can didate is Mrs. Ida Belle Camp bell who at present serves as rfeput commissioner in the of fice of the Commissioner of The Revenue. Incumbent Democratic candi dates who will appear on the bal lot in November include James Eugene Richardson, s h e r i f f  John Garland Plunkett, treas urer Harry Gordon Lawson, Commonwealths attorney Otho W. Martin, Jr., supervisor from the Stonewall District and pre sent chairman of the board of supervisors. Also, O. Hunter Tolley, supervisor, Cloverhill District. In addition, David Harold Ka- nipe is running for the office of justice of the peace, Cloverhill District and G e r a l d i n e R. Mitchell, justice of the peace, Southside District. The incumbent Commission er of The Revenue, John Curtis Caldwell, has announced his candidacy and will run as an Independent. Incumbent supervisor for the Southside District, John C.Cole, has indicated that he will run for the same office in November as an independent but has made no public announcement of this.

document.text: Lynchburg.Up to January 1, the department of public welfare had re ports of 896 births and 492 deaths, more of the former and less of the lat ter than Cynchburg has known in many years, and better averages in hoh respects than the city has ever known. Harrisonburg.  One Harrisonburg national bank paid a 12 per cent, di vidend to stockholders and a 10 per cent, bonus to employes for the year just closed, according to reports made at a meeting of stockholders. Two other hanks in the county are-said to have paid the same dividend. The largest banking institution in the coun ty paid 10 per cent. Norfolk.  Profits amounting to 2,000 weekly were frequently made in the whisky business in Portsmouth, affidavits filed with Commonwealths Attorney Albertson by special investi gators charge. The revelations con tained in affidavits which resulted in suspension of the police chief and two other officers charge the existence of a powerful liquor ring hacked by certain police officials. Lynchburg.A circular letter issued from the State headquarters here of the Virginia Farmers Educational and Co-Operative Union shows- that the union is arranging to quiz all candi dates for both branches of the State Legislature as they announce them selves for the election next November. The Information secured by the State union as to candidates will he given to the local unions throughout the State. Newport News.That the city of Newport News saved itself six or eight thousand dollars a year when it em  ployed a police justice at a salary of  4,000 a year In lieu of hail fees, is I shown by the statement of the police clerk for the first week In the new I year. Bail fees collected during that j week totaled more than 200, and the number of arrests made and persons bailed was comparatively small. Ar-  rests. a year ago were two or three I times, as numerous as at present which leads to the belief that the re cent police justice, who kept all fees in addition to his salary, made some thing like 12,000 or more annually. Danvifle.Morris Turk, a local mer chant, declares that he will endeavor to collect money on a treasury note issued by the Commonwealth of Vir ginia in 1862, and which, he claims, is due, with interest from that date. The amount involved, he declares, is now. 3,400, and he proposes to ask the State Auditor to honor it, and, failing that to make representations to the State Legislature. .The note, some what faded, is still in good condition. It bears the likeness of George Wash ington, is signed by C. S. Calvert, Treasurer, and J. M. Bennett, Auditor of Public Accounts, and bears the statement The faith of the Common wealth is pledged to secure payment. Winchester.Fruit growers of the Winchester district have been asked by H. F. Byrd, president of the Fred erick County Fruit Growers Associa tion, to attend an all-day meeting here lanuary 22 to consider the general sub ject of Growing Better Apples. Out- of-town speakers will include S. W. Fletcher, of the Pennsylvania State College J. P. Stewart, of Pennsyl vania M. B. Waite, of the United States Department of Agriculture D. Gold Miller, Inwood, W. Va. E. C. Auchter, of the Maryland Agricultural Station, College Park, Md., and T. S. Balston and R. L. Price, of the Vir ginia Extension Service, Blacksburg. DanvilleThe remains of Ballard Pruitt, a Danville marine, who died in France, arrived here and were re moved by an escort of former service men to the home of Mrs. Mollie Pruitt, on Henry street. Pruitt is the first Danville soldier to be brought home from France. Lynchburg.Police court fines here during 1920 aggregated 9,185.88 for city and 5,896 for State, .these amounts being double fines imposed in 1917. Increase in municipal ordinance fines are largely accounted for by en forcement of the city traffic laws.. Lynchburg.The City Council elect ed Mrs. W. J. DBell and Mrs. John W. Craddock to the school board, this be ing the first time women have been elected to public office here. The Council also provided for an increase of 50 cents a month for telephone serv ice for the remainder of the current year on all forms of service, except Individual business lines. The increase was granted over protest of several thousand residents In petitions filed t with the Council. The vote was 3 to 11 in favor o? the amendment

document.text: J. L. Hodges, state prohibi tion officer, 48,1 was shot and killed Tuesday morning by an alleged bootlegger near Ar vonia in Buckingham county, and up until this morning the engthened shadow of the arm a the law had searched the ountryside for his slayer. Commonwealths attorney Claude Wood, sheriff Jack Snoddy and a posse of several dozen officers, deputies and private citizens, aided by jloodhounds, lead the search Tor the alleged bootlegger. Hodges, accompanied by prohibition officer Arthur Scruggs, attempted to raid a itill on the small farm of Ben iimmerman. As they ap- aroached, they saw the stilr in iull operation within two hun dred yards of Zimmermans dwelling. They divided and- Scruggs came up from the 4  ir side and heard shots, rte dcirted closer and is said to have identified gimme,pan,  who had a shotgun Both opon- d -,re, ambushing themselvec behind trees. Scruggs had a revolver and was outclassed in I he duel add Zimmerman es caped. Scruggs then hurried to Arvonia for help and return ing the dead body of Hodges was located about fifty, yards from the still. V Scruggs declares he saw a colored man whom he did not recognize at the still. This I man escaped and is being sought.  , Woods surrounding the Zim merman farm has been closely searched yesterday and, last night in vain. Mr. Wood said yesterday, I still believe Zimmerman is hiding hearby. He has relatives in Petersburg land We have put .Peteceburg I officers on the lookout for him there. But he is the type who would hide in the woods for ft long time, being acqùaittted I with any number of hideouts. _ Zimermana wife is said t  her hiM

document.text: Fletcher For State Senate. Warrenton Special.  Complete returns from the Democratic primary give G. L. Fletcher fifty-three majori ty over T. C. Pilcher for the nomina tion for State senator from the coun ties of Loudoun and Fauquier. M. M. Green received the nomination for the house of delegates, defeating A. D. Kelly and Edward Ambler, the candidates, standing in tbe order named. J. A. C. Keith was nomi nated for Commonwealths attorney without opposition, and the remain ing county officers also, except for sheriff, and for this office A. S. Ham ilton defeated J. E. Oiinger by a large majority.

document.text: F A liM V IL L E .  Have you heard the whistles ! the engines as they come puffing in on our new roads?  a common salutation on our Streets now- a days, but as yet we have to be satisfied with the N.  W. and Tide wh ter  Western. Still we an hoping and what would life be with out it? The engineers tell us that Farmville is difficult of approach, and hence the ned ssity of the high bridge that the old Southside might enter our gates, and the Tidewatc t has to  Y in. I dont know just what the others will do in order t. come in and secure footing, but out gates stand wide open to receive them night and day. To give them proper welcome, however, we need to start the sounding of some nev whistles ourselves. The town must wake up or the trains will come and go unnoticed. Mr. W. T. Clark and his children have taken rooms at H, C. Pauletts and his new beautiful home on High Street rent. Mr. and Mrs. Lucken Bugg are snugly fixed in the Baldwin house on West High Street. Mr. Richard Cunningham, of Richmond, was a recent visitor in town. His mother and sisters, who are now living in Washington, D. C., will move to Richmond in the early Fall. Mrs. Joyner and child, of Suffolk, are guests in the home of Mr. Geo. Richardson. Mrs. Ellen C. Jones, who has an attractive home at Hampden-Sid- ney, has rented it to the Sigma Society and it will make a most de lightful club home. She will still have the use of the property during the vacation and there she and her daughters will continue to spend their summers. Miss Franke Jones, her eldest daughter and a recent graduate of the Normal has been offered posi tions in the High School at Char lottesville and also in that of Pearis- burg, Giles County, and all of our graduates, I am told sftre being well provided for. Virginia made nc mistake in establishing the Farm ville Female Normal nor in provid ing for it so liberally. The returns being made by her daughters is more than a hundred fold. Some new wheat is coming in a nd our faithful mill is busy night and day. Our farm horses begin to show the results of hard work on the farms, though as a general thing our farmers are taking better care of their stock than in years gone by Judge Mann, who is asking to be returned to the Senate from this district iB being opposed by Mr. Wallace, of Lunenburg. No joint discussions have been announced and I do not see where the fun of the present canvas is to come in at. No speaking, no treatin, no barbe cues, but just a dead, quiet and easy old campaign. No not an old- time campaign, but a modern day under the directions of the Barks dale Pure ? Election Law, The Citizens Bank in its bow to the public says that  the increas ing wealth and business of this community call for additional bank ing facilities to meet this growing need. Thats optimistic, the hope ful, cheerful salutation of young men. Of course they will succeed for in the lexicon of youth there is no such word as fail. Judge WatkinBhas no opposition for the position of Commonwealths Attorney, nor has Mr. Dickerson for the Sheriffalty, nor Mr. Owen for the House of Delegates. And in two districts aspirants for the Board of Supervisors will have walk overs Mr. Haskins in Leigh, and Dr. Holladay in Hampden. The spelling bee at the Summer Normal wag one of the interesting features oi the session. The Presbyteriaus have increased the salary of their pastor from 1,200 to 1,500, and this laborer is worthy of his hire.

document.text: Col. G. W. Hansbrough, one ot the ablest lawyers of Southwest Virginia and a promi nent republican leader, died at his residence In Salem, after an illness of a week of paraly- sis. He was born In Culpeper county August 16, 1828. After graduating In law from the University of Virginia he located In Taylor county, W. Va., where he was soon elected Commonwealths attorney. He was colonel ot the Ninth Virginia Infantry during the civil war and served till the close of hostilities with distinction and gallantry. He was severely wounded at the battle ot Alleghany mountain. At the restoration of peace he removed to his farm, near Salem, resumed tbe practice of law and soon en joyed a Urge and luoratlve practice. In 1883 he wag elected reporter of Le Supreme Court ot Appeals and served uatll tbe ex piration of his term iu 1895 Ho leaves a wife and one son, L O. Hansbrough, a mem ber of the Salem bar. A young mnn, named Frank Donnel l, ol Richmond, aged twenty-one years, was drowned near Homewood, on the James ilvor, by ailing from the excursion steamer Pocohontss. The firm ot Williams Brothers, produce dealers on Roanoke doek, were burned out All the stock on hand, including a lot ot peanuts, was lost, but the building was saved. Edward Richmond, coored, from Greens boro, N C , was shot In Lynchburg, and it is feared that the wound will prove fatal. The shooting was done by a white man named Wood, who olalms that the man wot l.i his watermelon patch. M B Noel, for many years In the stone business in Lynchburg, made an assignment for the benefit of creditors The assets are estimated at 2,500 liabilities not stated. Considerable excitement was caused In Boanoke by the attempt of a colored girl named Lulu Corellas to kill Capt. M. M. Rogers, a prominent citizen of Roanoke county, residing a short distance from tbe southern limits of this city. The girl had been employed as a domestic in Captain Rog ers family, but owing to her independence and Insolence was discharged a few days ago, after a very stormy scene In wblvh she declared she would kill Captain Rogers. About 9 oblock Sunday morning, as be wae riding on horseback to his place of business he was stopped by tbe girl, whom be told to call around at bis offloe later iu tbe day and he would pay her a small balancoduo her Just os he started to ride on some one called to him to look out and on turning bis head he found the girl pointing a pistol straight a him. In order to dtveit her aim ho rode di rectly toward her and as she stepped back she fired, but fortunately the bullet missed aim He then went in search of a police man, and while thus engaged the girl mad her way to the station-house and surrendered herself. The pistol was taken from her and found to be a 32-calibre of six chambers, two of which wero loaded. The first payment has been made by the New York, Philadelphia and Norfolk Railroad Company on the property just purchased at Pinners Point from tho Portsmouth Water Front Company, nnd plans - have been pre pared for extensive improvements in that locality. The Bouthorn Railway Company owners of tbe adjoining docks an l ware houses, has asked for an estimate from the New York Dredging Company for a founda tion for the largo colton compress which tho Southern purposes removing from City Point to Pinners Point by the time the fall business sets in. These operations are likely to give employment to a large building force for several montbe. Except In the ooal line, Pinners Point, with its three railroad lines, will soon outrival Lamberts Point in freight handling. At duek, Marshall Crow, nineteen years of age, son of Mr. Jno. T. Crow, a well-known citizen and former sheriff of Clark county, was accidentally shot and killed by another youth of about tbe same age. Geo. F, Night ingale, who with his father and mother, ot Washington, D. C., are spending the summer at the home ot the deceased boy in Berry- ville. Young Nightingale, thinking it was not loaded, snapped an old pistol at his roqra mate and friend, which the dead boy bad bmself loaded and laid away in a drawer a short time before. The ball pierced hii breast and he was instantly killed. Young Crow was greatly beloved, his bright mind high character and exemplary habits win ning for him the estoora of old and fonng. It Is said the corn farmors of Norfolk county are receiving some benefit from the hot Bans, and some of them will bull out very favorably, notwithstanding the serious wet season. The corn fanners, who as usual put in Irish potatoes, lost nearly all ot that crop, while It Is stated that tbe disastrous failure of the truckers crops has seriously involved many of them, they being deprived of the means to meet tbe bills of the fertilizer men, seedsmen, Ac. They have nothing left to ship except sweet potatoes. It is thought that a number of these now trucking will have to get out of the business.

document.text: B u c k in g h a m . Mr. 8. L. Holman was chosen as D em onstrator in farm work by the Board of Supervisors at their last meeting. There were only five ont of the six super visors present, Mr. M. L. Layne being the absent member. Mrs. A. 8. Hall went on a business trip to Columbia, S. C last week. On Monday night, the 21st of December the teachers and pupils of the Buckingham H ish School will give an entertain ment in the Court House build ing. Mrs. H. C. Glover and Miss M ary Glover have continued to be on the sick list and have been attended by Dr. G. L. Morriss Mis N annie Eldridge has re turned from a visit of several weeks in Richmond and is warding a t Mrs. Pearsons otel. A Mr W ard and his wife and one child have recently moved on a p art of the Jordan Taylor irac of land. These people have spent a good p art of their lives in cities, having come here from Chioago. It does sound strange, to hear of 5000 people being in en forced idleness in near-by R ich mond and so m a n f workers needed hers in the various lines of employment. The Civic League of Buck inghazn met on Friday night the 11th, and there was an in teresting debate on the ques tion of W omans Suffrage in Virginia. Commonwealths Attorney E. W. H ubard spoke in the affirmative, and Mr. A, O. G arnett and Miss Dora Armistead spoke in the nega tive. There was a vote taken to test the sense of the meet- ng on the question of woman suffrage and the vote resulted in nearly three to one against woman suffrage. The w eather w as so rainy and bad last week th a t little out door work could be done and the sohool officers coulc not get the necessary work done to the flue a t the Malone school and two teachers had to work in one room which was great inconvenience. The ladies of the Presbyter ian Church held their annua Bazaar a t Mrs. Pearsons hotel last Saturday they had been unable to carry out their plans before on account of the in clement weather. As I write on Monday morning the land is covered with snow and th e school girls and boys, who are off a t schoo are ju st hoping there will be no more falling w eather before they can come home. The girls at the Farm ville Normal were hoping to come on Friday, the 18 th, in an automobile, but doesnt look as if the machines will run then. People hereabouts have an abundance of wood to burn plenty of m eat, bread And fresh vegetables and fruits, and al of us should- be so thankful and so ready to divide w ith those less fortunate. Mr. Burley LeSeueur has sold out his interest a t Slate River Mills and has bought a farm and moved his fam ily, but has engaged to work in the mills until sometime in June. Our hopes of getting the new road to ride on Christm as are likely to be blighted by the m- clemen weather, as the con tractors can do but little such weather as we have been hav ing.

document.text: 1 The other candidate for the Legislature is Mr. R. L. Burke, who not only voted but worked l!or the adoption of the En abling Act by the voters of his oounty. We leve to vou to decide which man is most likelv to be of servidb to the prohibition cause in the next Legislature After the passage of the law by the General Assembly of 1916, the most important mat ter will be the proper enforce ment of the law, and the en forcement of the law is lodged very largely in the hands of the Commonwealths Attorney. We understand that there are two candidates for this office, one Mr S. L Ferguson, and the other Mr. W. C Franklin. The cord of these two men on prohibition is as follows Mr. Ferguson has been an active supported of prohibition legislation not only in his own hunty, but also was of great orvice in Richmond by bis ork with members of the jleneral Assembly. His record one of tbe best in the State the question of the prohibi tion of the manufacture and sale of ardent spirits. The records of Mr. Franklin that he has always been against prohibition, has voted against prohibition looally, and did so in the Statewide election. The voters of the county must decide which man is more likely to be energetic and suc cessful in his enforcement of the Statwide prohibitory law to be passed by the General Assembly This letter as you well under stand is not written becHUSe of any personal fee ing toward an of the four ni n ineii ion-d blit only that te. vott-rn ru  nave before t ern the refforii. .  tbe four men ci ncer Tnu prohibition. W ith best wisiths, I am , Y o u r. sincerely, J ames C annon J r 8 u p t Anti Sloon League of Virginie a d y
